Triggering Event:
Her phone buzzed, another "Sorry for your loss" message from some colleague or other. She'd heard it all before, even from people she barely knew. Like they were doing her a favor by sending a few words of condolence. As if that could fill the goddamn void in her chest.

She slammed her fist on the desk, making the coffee cup jump. "Fuck!" she spat, feeling the anger rise like bile. It was always there, bubbling under the surface, looking for an escape route. Today, it was the messages. Yesterday, it was the damn lawnmower that wouldn't start.

Her husband had been gone for six months now. Six fucking months of people tiptoeing around her, like she was made of glass. Like she couldn't handle a little anger, a little pain. She wasn't some fragile doll. She was a journalist, for chrissake. She'd seen and experienced more than most could imagine.

She grabbed her coat, shoving her arms into the sleeves with more force than necessary. She needed to get out of this house, away from these messages, away from the ghost of her husband that seemed to be everywhere. She needed to find a story, something real, something raw. Something that wouldn't send her condolence cards or treat her like she was breakable.

Her car keys jangled in her hand as she stormed out the door, each step echoing her anger. She was done with sympathy. Done with grief. It was time to get back into the game, time to find a story that would make people forget all about her loss. Time to make them see that she was still here, still fighting, still alive.
Generated Assessment:
Another pointless message from some soulless drone who thinks a few words can fill the abyss I'm drowning in. They have no idea what it's like to lose someone, to watch the world keep spinning while mine shattered into a million pieces. 

Six months and it feels like an eternity. Every day is just a reminder that he's really gone, that I'll never hear his laugh again, never feel his touch. The memories haunt me like a ghost, refusing to let me move on. And yet, everyone around me seems so... cheerful. Like they're trying to pretend that everything is fine, that my heart isn't heavy with grief.

I glance at my reflection in the window, and for a moment, I don't recognize the person staring back. My eyes look sunken, my skin pale. I look like a shadow of my former self. But what choice do I have? I've lost the one person who truly understood me, who truly loved me. Now I'm left to pick up the pieces of a life that's been forever changed.

I take a deep breath, trying to shake off the suffocating weight of my emotions. But it's no use. The pain is always there, lurking beneath the surface, waiting to pounce. And when it does, I'm left feeling like I'm drowning in a sea of despair.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Dr. Amelia Hartley, 62-year-old scientist and recipient of countless awards for her groundbreaking research in astrophysics, was having one of those days where even the stars seemed to be conspiring against her. She'd spent hours meticulously preparing her keynote speech for the upcoming International Astronomy Conference, only for her partner, Richard, to "accidentally" spill his coffee on her laptop while she was out getting them lunch.

"Well, isn't that just peachy," Amelia muttered sarcastically, glaring at the now-useless device. She'd have to start from scratch, and with the conference in two days, time wasn't exactly on her side. As if reading her thoughts, Richard breezed into the room, completely oblivious to the chaos he'd caused.

"Amelia, darling," he said, flashing his charming smile, "I've got tickets for us to that new exhibition at the museum tonight. Thought it might help take your mind off work."

Amelia raised an eyebrow. "You mean the one I specifically told you I didn't have time for because of this conference? The one where I'm supposed to be presenting my life's work?"

Richard waved a hand dismissively. "Oh, come on, Amelia. It's not like they'll notice if you're not there. You've given enough talks in your lifetime."

Vengefulness, long dormant beneath her usually composed demeanor, began to stir. She took a deep breath, counting silently to ten before responding in a voice as cold as the distant galaxies she studied.

"You know what, Richard? I think I will go to that exhibition tonight. Alone. Maybe they'll notice my absence there too."

As he opened his mouth to protest, Amelia held up a hand, her eyes flashing with a challenge he hadn't seen since their early days together. "And don't bother asking where the laptop is. It's taking a well-deserved 'holiday' in the trash can."
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, today is just one of those days, you know? I swear, everything is going wrong. First, I spilled coffee all over my laptop - again! Can't believe Richard did that on purpose, though. He always thinks he's so clever, doesn't he? 

I was really looking forward to giving that keynote speech, but now...now it's all ruined. Two whole days until the conference, and I still need to redo the presentation. And Richard, bless his heart, just walked in here like nothing happened. Like, hello, my entire career is on the line!

He tries to cheer me up by suggesting we go to that new exhibit tonight, but honestly, who has time for that? Not me, that's for sure. And besides, I've already told him I don't want to go. But does he listen? Nope. Just keeps smiling and telling me it's no big deal.

It's not a big deal?! Are you kidding me? This is my chance to present my life's work, and he's just brushing it off like it's nothing. I'm starting to feel like I'm not good enough, like I'll never amount to anything. 

But then he says something about how many talks I've given in my lifetime, and I just...I just lose it. Why would he say that? Doesn't he care that I'm stressing out over this?! It's not funny, Richard. It's not a joke.

Okay, okay, I need to calm down. I won't let him get to me. I'll just go to that exhibit tonight, alone, and show him what I'm capable of. Who needs him anyway?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In her ninth hour at the newsroom, Emma's fingers paused over the keyboard as she noticed the clock. It was past midnight again, another deadline looming like an unseen specter. Her partner, Tom, had left hours ago, his goodbye kiss still lingering on her cheek, while she remained ensconced in the fluorescent glow of her desk lamp.

She had been at this for years, yet tonight, every word felt heavier than the last, each letter a tiny boulder pushing against her tired eyes. Her mind wandered to Tom's warm bed, now empty and cold without him. She imagined his arms around her, his steady heartbeat lulling her to sleep. But duty called, and Emma was nothing if not dutiful.

Her phone buzzed, breaking the quiet. It was Tom, checking in. "Still at it, I see," he wrote. She sighed, typing out a reply that was more obligation than affection. Her heart felt heavy with fatigue, each beat echoing her resentment like a dull thud against her ribcage.

Just then, her editor appeared beside her desk, his face etched with lines of impatience. "Emma, where's your piece on the city council meeting?" he asked, his voice barely above a whisper but laden with implication.

Emma blinked at him, her mind struggling to connect the dots between her current task and the one he mentioned. She felt a flicker of annoyance. Wasn't it enough that she was already burning the midnight oil? Did they have to pile on more work?

"I'm almost done with the mayor's speech," she said, her voice level but tense. "I'll get to the council meeting notes once I'm finished here."

Her editor nodded, but his expression remained stern. "We need both pieces by morning, Emma. Don't forget, we're running on a tight schedule." With that, he disappeared into his office, leaving Emma with her thoughts and her screen full of unyielding words.

As she turned back to her work, Emma couldn't shake off the feeling of unease. She was tired, yes, but there was something else gnawing at her. A sense of being taken for granted, perhaps? Or was it self-doubt creeping in, whispering lies about her worth?

Either way, she knew one thing for certain: tonight's deadline wouldn't be the last. It was a never-ending cycle, and Emma was caught in its relentless spin, no matter how much she yearned for rest and peace.
Generated Assessment:
I've been working non-stop since dawn, my body screaming for respite as the sun dips below the horizon. The fluorescent lights overhead seem to mock me, casting an unforgiving glare on the endless expanse of code before me. My mind is numb, a hollow vessel devoid of creativity or passion.

Tom's parting words still linger, but what's the point of holding onto those fleeting moments of comfort? They're just a distraction from the crushing weight of deadlines and expectations. His absence is a constant reminder that I'm alone in this battle, fighting a losing war against the clock.

My phone buzzes, shrill and jarring, shattering the fragile illusion of solitude. Tom's message is a cruel taunt, a harsh reminder that even in the midst of chaos, I'm expected to perform. My response is a mechanical exercise, a hollow echo of obligation rather than genuine connection.

The editor's presence is a harbinger of doom, his eyes boring into mine like cold, calculating instruments. He doesn't care about my well-being; all he cares about is the product, the end result. I'm just a cog in his machine, a replaceable part in the grand symphony of production.

I push aside the nagging sense of resentment, attributing it to mere exhaustion. It's not about being taken for granted; it's about being driven by sheer willpower. I'll power through the night, fueled by adrenaline and determination. Tomorrow will bring new challenges, but I'll face them head-on, undaunted and unbroken.

This cycle won't end until I surrender, until I acknowledge defeat. But I won't give in. Not yet. Not ever.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the heart of the bustling hospital corridor, Dr. Harriet Thompson, 66 and as sharp as ever, was walking briskly towards her office after another grueling shift. Her partner of 20 years, Martha, a nurse manager, had been trying to reach her all day. Harriet's phone buzzed again - voicemail number five from Martha.

"Damn it," Harriet muttered under her breath, her anger simmering like the steam rising from the hospital's old radiators. She was tired of being ignored by the admin staff, tired of fighting for more resources, and now Martha was piling on more work without so much as a 'please' or 'thank you'.

She stormed into her office, kicking the door shut behind her. Her desk was a mess, strewn with charts and papers that seemed to have multiplied overnight. In the middle of it all, she found Martha's note: "Urgent! Please review these cases before morning rounds."

Harriet's grip tightened on the note until it crumpled in her fist. She felt a surge of anger at being taken for granted, at the lack of respect for her time and expertise. She was more than just another doctor around here; she had built this hospital up from nothing.

"Fine," Harriet spat out, pushing the mess aside to clear space for her laptop. "I'll do your damn work, Martha. But you owe me one."

As she began typing, she could feel her anger morphing into determination. She wouldn't let anyone push her around, not now, not ever. She was Dr. Harriet Thompson, and she deserved better than this.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, can't believe I'm stuck in this dump. Twenty years of my life, building this hospital from scratch, and what do I get? Ignored by the admin staff, overworked, and undervalued. They think I'm just some old doc who can't keep up, but they're wrong. I'm still sharper than most of them combined.

Martha's always on my case about something. Can't even get a simple message through to me without it being a chore. And now she's dumping all these cases on me like I'm some kind of miracle worker. Newsflash, Martha: I'm not invincible.

This place is a disaster. The radiators are always leaking, the equipment's outdated, and don't even get me started on the paperwork. It's like they expect me to perform miracles with all the crap they throw at me.

And Martha thinks she's so great with her little notes and her "urgent" messages. Like I haven't got better things to do than babysit her workload. I swear, sometimes I wonder how she makes it through the day without completely losing her mind.

But you know what really gets my blood boiling? It's the fact that no one appreciates me. No one recognizes all the hard work I've put in over the years. I'm the one who built this hospital, who trained the nurses, who kept this place running despite all the odds against us. And do I get any recognition? Nope.

So yeah, I'll do Martha's work. I'll do whatever it takes to prove to her, to everyone else, that I'm still relevant. Because if I don't, who will? This place would fall apart without me, and we both know it.

Fine, I'll get to work. But don't expect me to smile and wave while I'm doing it. I'm not some happy little nurse's aide. I'm Dr. Harriet Thompson, and I deserve better.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In his lab coat-stained study, Dr. Harold "Harry" Thompson was meticulously calibrating his latest invention when he noticed it - a dusty photograph tucked behind a stack of scientific journals. It was them, him and Emily, grinning foolishly at some long-forgotten conference in Berlin.

"You still here, Emily?" Harry muttered, tracing her image with a trembling finger. "Five years gone, yet you're as stubborn as any constant I've ever studied."

He sighed, placing the photograph face down on his desk. He'd promised himself he wouldn't be so sentimental anymore. After all, he was a man of science, not some maudlin poet.

But then, the door creaked open. Harry turned to see who had disturbed him, expecting one of the lab assistants. Instead, it was Emily's old favorite chair, swaying gently into the room as if she were pushing it from behind.

Harry blinked, rubbing his eyes. "Not now, Emily," he whispered, but the chair kept advancing, bumping against his desk with a soft thud. He shook his head, chuckling bitterly. "Very well, have your little joke. But remember, I'm not some foolish romantic. I'm just... sad."

As he reached for the photograph, intending to tuck it away again, he noticed something peculiar: Emily's image seemed to shimmer, like heat rising from asphalt on a summer day. Harry squinted, leaning closer until...

"Emily?" he breathed, his heart pounding in his chest like a faulty experiment gone awry. Because there, just visible beneath her smiling face, was an inscription he'd never noticed before:

*For my dear Harry - Until the end of time.*

Harry snorted, running a hand through his thinning hair. "Oh, Emily," he said, laughter threatening to spill from him like an overflowing beaker. "You always did have a flair for the dramatic." And with that, he scooped up the photograph, pressing it to his heart as tears stung his eyes - sad, yes, but also strangely, wonderfully amused.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, what if I really am losing my mind? Five years since Emily left, and I'm still stuck in this rut. What if I'm just pretending to be over her? What if I'm just using science as a distraction from the pain?

I glance around my cluttered lab, trying to shake off the feeling of emptiness. The dusty photo behind the journals catches my eye, and I feel a familiar pang. What if I'm just holding onto the past because it's easier than facing reality? What if I'll never find someone else like Emily?

That chair, though – it's been sitting there for years, silently mocking me. What if it's more than just a piece of furniture? What if it's a reminder that Emily's still out there, laughing at me from beyond the grave?

I try to push the thought away, telling myself I'm just being ridiculous. But what if I'm right? What if Emily's watching me from somewhere, waiting for me to realize my true feelings? What if I'm just too blind to see it?

I force myself to look away from the photo, but my gaze keeps drifting back. That inscription – *For my dear Harry - Until the end of time.* – it's like a cruel joke. What if it's true? What if Emily's still waiting for me, even after all these years?

I take a deep breath, trying to calm down. It's just a silly superstition, I tell myself. But what if it's not? What if I'm just delaying the inevitable, refusing to accept that Emily's really gone?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event: "I've spent my goddamn life in that lab, making groundbreaking discoveries while he was out there playing fucking househusband! And now, after I finally pushed for the divorce, he has the audacity to ask for half of my pension? Over my dead body!" She slammed her fist on the desk, scattering papers and sending a glass vial crashing to the floor. "He's gonna pay for this, I swear to god."
Generated Assessment:
I just can't believe he's doing this to me. I thought we were happy, or at least, I thought I was happy. But what if I wasn't really happy? What if I was just pretending to be okay so I wouldn't hurt him? 

I keep thinking about all the times he left for work and I was alone, feeling so empty and unfulfilled. What if I had just been more patient? What if I had just been more understanding? Maybe things would have turned out differently. 

But no, instead I'm stuck here, fighting for every penny, every scrap of dignity. What if I lose everything? What if I end up living in some dingy apartment, struggling to make ends meet? The thought of it keeps me up at night, wondering how it could have come to this.

I try to focus on the future, but my mind keeps wandering back to the past. What if I had spoken up sooner? What if I had stood up for myself sooner? Would things be better now? I don't know, maybe they would have been worse. But what if...?

Sometimes I wonder if I was just too blind to see the signs. Was I too caught up in our relationship to notice when he was pulling away? What if I had seen it earlier? Would I have done anything differently? I'll never know, but the what-ifs haunt me still.

It's hard to shake the feeling that I'm somehow responsible for his decision. What if I had been more supportive? More loving? Had I shown him enough affection, enough care? The doubts creep in, and before I know it, I'm lost in a sea of possibilities, each one leading down a darker path.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Dr. Amelia Hart stood in her kitchen, staring at the goddamn stack of mail that had piled up like some fucked-up Jenga tower while she'd been on call. She was running on fumes and a half-eaten protein bar, her divorce papers tucked neatly into her neglected mailbox right next to the bills.

She grabbed the top envelope, tearing it open with more force than necessary. A credit card offer fluttered out, landing face-down on the counter like a fucking insult. She picked it up, reading aloud, "Congratulations, Dr. Hart! You've been pre-approved for a credit limit increase!"

Amelia scoffed, tossing the card onto the counter. "Fuck you too," she muttered.

Next was a bill, then another, all of them unopened, unpaid. She could feel her blood pressure rising like the damn thermometer in her clinic. Then, there it was. The thick, official-looking envelope from her lawyer. She hesitated, her fingers tracing the familiar name printed on the return address.

With a sigh that bordered on a growl, she ripped open the envelope. It was just a formality, she told herself. A fucking rubber stamp on what had already been decided in court. She unfolded the papers, scanning them quickly before her eyes landed on the words, "Your former spouse has requested to have your son's primary custody."

Amelia's heart stopped for a moment, then it felt like it was trying to break out of her chest. She crumpled the papers, throwing them into the sink with more force than she intended. They bounced off the stainless steel and landed in the empty sink, staring up at her like another fucking insult.

She leaned against the counter, her head throbbing. "Fuck," she whispered, feeling the familiar sting of tears threatening to spill over. She wiped them away angrily, grabbing a glass from the cabinet with more force than necessary. It shattered in her hand, cutting into her palm.

"Shit!" she exclaimed, looking down at the blood dripping onto the floor. She grabbed a towel, pressing it against the cut as she kicked the broken glass aside. This was just fucking perfect.

She leaned back against the counter, sliding down to the floor, her knees pulled up to her chest. She rested her forehead on her knees, letting out a deep breath that sounded more like a defeated laugh.

"Well, fuck me," she said to the empty room. "It's not enough that he took my marriage, now he wants to take my son too."
Generated Assessment:
As I stood amidst this chaotic landscape, the sheer weight of responsibility threatened to suffocate me. My mind recoiled at the thought of those bills piling up, a constant reminder of my failure to manage my finances. How could I have let things get so out of hand? I should be better than this. I'm a doctor, after all. I should be able to keep track of my expenses.

But no, instead I find myself drowning in a sea of debt, with nary a lifeline in sight. And to make matters worse, that letter from my lawyer. I knew it was coming, but still, the news stung. My ex's request for primary custody – it's simply unacceptable. I should be able to provide a stable environment for our child, but apparently, I'm not capable of doing even that.

Why must everything conspire against me? First, my marriage falls apart, and now this. It's as if the universe is conspiring to destroy my life. I should be stronger than this, more resilient. But the truth is, I'm exhausted, both physically and emotionally. I'm barely holding on, and yet, I expect myself to be perfect?

I glance around the room, taking in the scattered bills and the shattered glass. It's a mess, a reflection of my inner turmoil. I should be able to clean up this chaos, put everything back in order. But for now, I'm stuck in this rut, unable to escape the weight of my own expectations.

Perhaps I'm just setting myself up for disappointment. Maybe I'll never be able to get my finances in order, or provide a stable home for my child. The thought sends a wave of despair crashing through me. I should be angry, I should be fighting, but all I can do is sit here, feeling helpless and defeated.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet of her classroom after hours, she was bent over, grading papers by the dim glow of her desk lamp. The silence was comforting, usual. But tonight, it felt... heavy. She couldn't shake off the feeling that she wasn't alone.

A sudden gust of wind rattled the window behind her, making her jump. "Shit," she muttered under her breath, her heart pounding like a drum in her chest. She took a deep breath, trying to calm herself. "It's just the wind, for fuck's sake," she whispered, attempting to convince herself.

But when she heard it again—a soft creaking from the door—she froze. She hadn't imagined that. Her eyes widened as she slowly turned around, her heart now threatening to break through her ribcage. The door was slightly ajar, swaying gently in the draft.

She couldn't remember if she'd closed it properly earlier. Panic began to rise like bile in her throat. She wanted to scream for help, but her voice seemed stuck in her lungs. She could hear every little sound now—the ticking of the clock, the rustling of papers on her desk, even the distant hum of traffic outside.

She reached for her phone, hands shaking so badly she dropped it twice before managing to dial her partner's number. No answer. "Fuck," she hissed, feeling a wave of fear crashing over her. She was alone in this godforsaken school, and something—or someone—was out there with her.
Generated Assessment:
Are you kidding me? I'm either completely safe and sound in my classroom, or some psycho killer is stalking me, waiting to pounce. There's no middle ground, no gray area. If I'm not hearing every creak and groan of the old building, it means nothing bad is happening. And if I am hearing everything, then I'm basically begging for death.

One minute I'm fine, the next I'm convinced I'm going to die. It's like my brain is playing some sick game of Russian roulette. Either I'm a genius who can handle anything life throws at me, or I'm a total wimp who can't even survive a night in an empty classroom.

And don't even get me started on the possibility of someone breaking in. That's just too much to handle. I mean, what if they're armed? What if they're crazy? What if they're... *gulp*...the Boogeyman?

No, I need to get out of here, NOW. I'll call my partner, make sure they know where I am. Maybe they can come pick me up, take me to safety. Or maybe I'll just lock myself in the supply closet until morning. I mean, it's better than being out here, vulnerable.

But wait, what if the door isn't locked? What if someone is already inside, watching me right now? *shudder* Okay, okay, I've had enough. I'm getting out of here, no matter what. Time to bail, before things get any worse.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
"At 3 AM, another long shift finally over, Jake unlocked his front door. His wife's ghost still lingered in every corner of their once shared home. He felt it, that empty pit in his stomach, that gnawing insecurity. Every time he saw her picture on the mantel, he'd think, "She should be here." But she wasn't. Cancer had stolen her from him, leaving him alone with their echoes.

He flipped on the light, expecting to see her smiling face, hear her laugh. Instead, there was silence and a note. His mother-in-law's neat handwriting told him she'd been by while he was at work, cleaning up, "making sure you're eating right." Jake bristled. He wasn't some kid who needed looking after. Couldn't they all just leave him alone?

He tossed the note onto the counter, his heart pounding. It was always like this - every reminder of Emma sent him spiraling into this insecure place where he felt like a fraud, like he'd never been enough for her. He wanted to scream at the walls, demand someone tell him why she left him behind.

Instead, Jake sank to the floor, head in his hands, tears streaming down his face. He was alone, truly alone, and it fucking hurt."
Generated Assessment:
As I walked through the quiet streets, I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease. The streetlights cast long shadows, making me wonder if anyone was watching me. I quickened my pace, glancing over my shoulder as if expecting someone to jump out and startle me. It's just nerves, I told myself, but the feeling persisted.

I arrived at the office, and my coworker, Rachel, greeted me with a warm smile. She asked how my weekend was, and I found myself becoming defensive, explaining that I'd spent it alone, reorganizing my apartment. Rachel seemed concerned, asking if everything was okay, but I brushed it off, saying I was fine. Why would she care? We were colleagues, after all.

Later that day, our team lead, Michael, called a meeting to discuss the upcoming project. As we brainstormed ideas, I noticed that one of my colleagues, Alex, kept interrupting, dominating the conversation. I felt a surge of frustration, thinking that Alex was trying to undermine my contributions. But when I brought it up, Michael simply suggested we take a break and revisit the topic later. I realized that maybe I was reading too much into it.

Despite the chaos around me, I couldn't shake the feeling that everyone was conspiring against me. It was as if they were waiting for me to slip up so they could pounce. I tried to focus on the task at hand, but my mind kept wandering back to the same thought: what if they're all plotting something?<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In her decades-spanning career at TechCorp, Martha had seen it all: mergers, layoffs, even a CEO impeachment. But today, as she sat in her ergonomic chair, eyes scanning lines of code that once danced before her like poetry, she felt a chill. Her heart throbbed in her chest like an old, worn-out server.

"Damn it," she muttered, squinting at the screen. The code was... wrong. It wasn't just a typo or a logical error; it was as if someone had purposefully sabotaged it. But who? And why?

Her mind raced, worry gnawing at her like a relentless virus. She couldn't remember the last time she'd seen such chaos in her beloved code. It was like finding graffiti in an ancient library. She took a deep breath, trying to calm herself. This wasn't like her. She was Martha, the rock of TechCorp, the one who could solve any problem with just a few keystrokes.

But today, she felt... old. Her fingers hesitated over the keyboard, unsure. And that worried her more than anything else.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, what's going on here? I swear, I can feel John's frustration radiating off his screen. He's been working non-stop on this project for months, and now it's just... broken. Like, seriously, how hard is it to write some decent code? I've seen high schoolers do better than this.

And don't even get me started on the comments. "Optimize for performance"? Are you kidding me? That's just code-speak for "I have no idea what I'm doing." I mean, come on, John, didn't you learn anything from our last meeting about the importance of readability?

I take a deep breath, trying to calm myself down. Maybe I'm just being too harsh. Maybe John really did try his best. But honestly, it feels like he's just phoning it in. Like, he's going through the motions, but he doesn't actually care about the outcome.

My mind starts racing with worst-case scenarios. What if this is just the beginning? What if John's incompetence is going to bring down the entire project? I shake my head, trying to clear it. No, no, no. I need to focus on finding a solution, not dwelling on John's obvious lack of skill.

But the doubt lingers, like a shadow in the corner of my mind. Did John really sabotage this code on purpose? Or am I just reading too much into it? I push the thought aside, telling myself I'm being paranoid. But the feeling persists, like a nagging voice in my head.<|eot_id|>
